title: Aussie diner horrified to find battery in meal from popular chain restaurant
text:
A Queensland woman was gobsmacked when she discovered what appeared to be a battery in her takeaway dinner from ﻿a popular Mexican chain.

Stephanie Weston ordered a beef mince burrito bowl from Guzman y Gomez at Ripley, south-west of Brisbane, last Friday.

Her partner picked it up at the drive-through and brought it home to Weston, who dug in before she spotted something small and metallic in the meal.

READ MORE: Trump says he was unaware of theories that he was dead

What appears to be a button battery in a Guzman y Gomez burrito bowl. (Facebook/Stephanie Weston)

Upon closer inspection, it appeared to be a button battery.

If ingested, they can cause severe chemical burns and internal injuries﻿ that can turn life-threatening.

Weston told the ABC she "panicked" when she realised what it was.﻿

Horrified, ﻿she snapped a photo while her partner returned to the fast food restaurant to show staff the battery.

READ MORE: Military specialists join manhunt for Dezi Freeman

A Guzman y Gomez assistant manager reportedly said the battery had come from a food thermometer.

Weston's partner was offered a refund and two burrito vouchers as compensation.﻿

Unimpressed with the restaurant's response, ﻿Weston posted a photo of her meal to Facebook with the caption: "Well I'm not eating Guzman y Gomez Ripley again, I found a battery in my burrito bowl and they think voucher makes up for almost posioning myself."

A ﻿Guzman y Gomez spokesperson told 9news.com.au they were aware of the photo "displaying a foreign object in a meal from our Ripley restaurant" doing the rounds online.

The Guzman y Gomez restaurant at Ripley, southwest of Brisbane. (Guzman y Gomez)

"We have been in contact with the guest who was involved," they said.

"GYG immediately initiated a full investigation into this matter and confirmed that the object came from a food-grade thermometer.

"This is an isolated incident, there is no alert or recall that is required on this matter."

The spokesperson said ﻿Guzman y Gomez had "undertaken urgent actions to ensure that this does not happen again".

That includes replacing the model of thermometer involved in the incident, training crew and running ﻿additional checks of equipment across all restaurants

"Food safety is our absolute priority at GYG, and we take incidents of this nature extremely seriously," the spokesperson said.

title: Google will not be forced to sell off Chrome or Android, US judge rules
text:
A court will not force Google to sell off its Chrome browser or Android, a US federal judge has said in a court filing.

The decision overnight serves as a significant win for the tech company, which has avoided the most extreme possible outcome from a landmark antitrust case that determined the company was operating an illegal online search monopoly.

Although Google will not be forced to sell of its Chrome browser or Android, it will have to make certain search data available to qualified competitors to promote competition.

READ MORE: Trump says he was unaware of theories that he was dead

A court will not force Google to sell off its Chrome browser or Android. (CNN)

It will also be barred from entering into or maintaining exclusive contracts related to the distribution of services like Chrome, Search, the Google Assistant and its Gemini app.

Those agreements provide a significant source of revenue for Google and broad access to its services, although the company had proposed ditching those contracts as a potential remedy in the case.

US District Court Judge Amit Mehta said in a ruling that he had accepted Google's proposed remedies, in part.

The trial put Google's core business under a microscope at a time when it is already under threat of being toppled by AI chatbots.

And it comes as the company is also gearing up to defend the operation of its online advertising business after it, too, was found to be an illegal monopoly earlier this year.

"Google will not be required to divest Chrome; nor will the court include a contingent divestiture of the Android operating system in the final judgment," the filing read.

Google did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

CNN has reached out to the Justice Department for comment.

The ruling was closely watched across Silicon Valley, as other major tech giants are also fighting antitrust cases brought by the US government.

Mehta wrote that the rise of generative AI tools have "changed the course of this case," adding that ensuring Google's dominance in search doesn't "carry over into the GenAI space" was a key part of the remedies proceedings.

"And, unlike the typical case where the court's job is to resolve a dispute based on historic facts, here the court is asked to gaze into a crystal ball and look to the future," he wrote.

"Not exactly a judge's forte."

Mehta ruled last fall that Google had violated US antitrust law with its search business, writing that the company "is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly."

In the weekslong "remedies" portion of the trial, Google argued that the Justice Department's proposed solutions would harm consumers by making it harder to access their preferred search engine and could stunt the US economy and American tech leadership.

The trial put Google's core business under a microscope. (Getty)

Chrome leader Parisa Tabriz testified that forcing Google to sell off Chrome would result in a "shadow of the current" web browser and would likely make it "insecure and obsolete."

Google has for years inked exclusive, multibillion-dollar contracts with device makers like Apple to secure its position as the default search provider on smartphones and web browsers, encouraging its dominance giving it what the court sees as being an unfair advantage that relies on consumer habit rather than choice.

By 2020, 95 per cent of all US search queries on mobile devices went through Google, Mehta noted in his opinion.

The move to prevent Google from entering into exclusive distribution deals is the court's way of levelling the playing field.

Google will be barred from entering into agreements that require companies to preload Google Search, Chrome, the Google Assistant or Gemini in order to license its popular Google Play app store.

But many phone makers will likely still include Google's services because of their popularity, said Carolina Milanesi, president and principal analyst at tech research firm Creative Strategies.

"The value that these companies bring to the vendors and the people that partner with them is such that I don't know how many will decide not to preload their services," she said.

Google will still be allowed to pay partners to distribute its services – including its Search engine – on their products.

Apple and Google have a lucrative deal in which the search giant pays the iPhone maker billions to be the default search engine on its web browser. Ending that partnership would have meant Google would no longer get default distribution on one of the world's most popular smartphones, while yanking a lucrative source of revenue from Apple.

"Cutting off payments from Google almost certainly will impose substantial—in some cases, crippling—downstream harms to distribution partners, related markets, and consumers, which counsels against a broad payment ban," the filing read.

Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives sees the ruling as a win for both Apple and Google, particularly following a Bloomberg report that the two companies may partner to incorporate Gemini into Siri.

"While in theory Google is barred from 'exclusive deals' for search this now lays the groundwork for Apple to continue its deal and ultimately likely double down on more AI-related partnership with Google Gemini down the road," he said in a research note.

The outcome is a win for Google overall, says Robert Siegel, lecturer in management at the Stanford School of Business.

But the decision to prohibit Google from entering into exclusive contracts means the company may have to try a little harder to entice consumers moving forward, especially amid heightened competition from rivals like OpenAI and Perplexity – the latter of which made an unsolicited, far-fetched offer to buy Chrome last month.

title: Why some Aussies are turning their back on university for TAFE
text:
Leaving high school and entering university used to be the norm for Australians , but that is now beginning to change.

Fewer Aussies are now enrolling in university than any point in the last decade, with figures from the Federal Department of Education revealing university enrolments for domestic students sinking in both 2022 and 2023, after peaking in 2021.

Around 396,000 domestic students enrolled in university in 2023, the lowest rate in the last 10 years and a drop of 22 per cent compared to the enrolment numbers before the pandemic.

Could TAFE programs across Australia profit from falling enrolment numbers at Aussie universities? (Louise Kennerley)

Data also revealed a quarter of students who began university in 2017 had dropped by the end of 2022, the second-highest dropout rate on record.

These revelations come as leading universities around the country are slashing budgets, staff numbers and course offerings.

Last month , the University of Technology Sydney suspended enrolments for over 100 courses amid rumours of 400 teaching jobs being made redundant.

Meanwhile, TAFE enrolments are on the rise, thanks to incentives such as fee-free courses.

This has seen TAFE numbers in NSW recover and rise to around 404,000 at the end of 2024.

One Aussie who left university for TAFE is Sydney, who commenced a Bachelor of Engineering at UTS in 2016.

She never finished her degree, instead completing a Certificate IV in Engineering Drafting in 2022.

Sydney told 9news.com.au the fee-free incentives were a big motivator, and said the style of teaching differed between TAFE and her experience at university.

Sydney is one of many people who turned their back on university in favour of TAFE. (TAFE NSW/Supplied)

"Teachers [at TAFE] definitely care about you more, feedback is more personalised," she said.

"Some lecturers and tutors [at university] are very helpful and others kind of don't care.

"It feels like teaching is teaching, and caring about students is secondary."

TAFE NSW is actively recruiting women to enter their courses as it looks to fill skills shortages, and indicated future programs were in the pipeline.

"We deliver a range of programs and short courses designed to give high school students a taste of vocational education, encourage more women to consider careers in trades, and support people to upskill or reskill," a TAFE NSW spokesperson told 9news.com.au.

Sydney's course took one year and included work placement, which helped her get a full-time job at an engineering firm in Parramatta in Sydney's west.

"I got industry experience at the same time as studying TAFE," she said.

"TAFE gave me a more hands-on experience in terms of learning programs and things like that, whereas at uni, the onus is on you to learn the program."

title: Kim Jong-un arrives in Beijing in lavish but slow-moving armoured train
text:
As a select group of world leaders prepares to roll into Beijing for a massive military parade on Wednesday, one has travelled in his signature armoured green train: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un .

The old-fashioned train has become a symbol of Kim's dynasty and his secluded nation. It has also long been the subject of intrigue, carrying generations of the Kim family across the country and on rare international trips.

North Korean state media confirmed on Tuesday night that Kim's train had arrived in Beijing. When he crossed into China earlier in the day, photos showed the leader smiling on board the train, sitting at a wooden table with a North Korean flag behind him.

North Korea leader Kim Jong Un waves from a train in Pyongyang, North Korea. (KCNA)

He's accompanied by senior officials including Foreign Minister Choe Son Hui, according to the country's foreign ministry.

Kim's father and predecessor, Kim Jong Il, was reportedly averse to flying and relied heavily on the train, according to Reuters.

In one instance in 2002, Russian state media showed images of the train – green with yellow striping – when Kim Jong Il visited Russia during a brief period of relaxed sanctions that allowed greater engagement with the outside world.

Both Kim's father and grandfather reportedly hosted lavish dinners aboard. One account published in 2002 by Russian official Konstantin Pulikovsky claimed that the train carried cases of Bordeaux and Beaujolais wine from Paris, and that passengers feasted on live lobster and pork barbecue.

But that brief period of openness and luxury ended quickly, with international sanctions clamping back down in 2003. Though very little information from the isolated nation reaches the outside world now, reports indicate severe impoverishment and malnourishment throughout much of the country.

The train is famously slow-moving and tight on security. It's so heavily armoured that it travels at an average speed of 60km/h, according to a 2009 report in South Korean newspaper Chosun Ilbo.

A special train carrying North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. (Kyodo/CNN)

It contained conference rooms, an audience chamber and bedrooms and featured satellite phone connections and flat screen televisions, the paper reported at the time. In Kim Jong Il's time, some 20 stations were built for the family train, the paper said.

Kim has used this train on several trips abroad, though he has also previously travelled by plane and private jet.

Kim rode the train during his last international visit – a 2023 trip to Russia's far east to meet with his counterpart Vladimir Putin. Photos released by state media at the time offered a glimpse into the locomotive, showing polished wooden floors and an ornately decorated white doorway.

State media footage released in 2022 showed Kim working in his office on board the train, and also relaxing on board while smoking a cigarette in a short-sleeved shirt, according to South Korean news agency Yonhap.

And during a 2018 trip when Kim met Chinese leader Xi Jinping, footage by North Korean state media showed Chinese officials boarding the train to greet Kim. The delegations held talks on board, sitting on two rows of pink couches, photos showed.

Besides international travel, the train has also been featured in state propaganda, with the Kim family going on long train journeys to meet ordinary North Koreans, Reuters reported.

A life-sized model of one of the train's carriages is displayed in a mausoleum outside the North Korean capital Pyongyang, where the remains of Kim's father and grandfather are kept.

title: Stray pup needs adoption after battling crocs in Queensland's far north
text:
A family of stray dogs from Far North Queensland, dubbed the "Furwins" due to their encounters with crocodiles, have been rescued and relocated to the Gold Coast .

The mother, named Terri, and her pups were initially spotted by locals while struggling to survive in the remote region.

Remote Animal Assistance (RAA) intervened to rescue the dogs, finding Terri in a critical condition.

The mother, named Terri, and her pups were initially spotted by locals while struggling to survive in the remote region. (Nine)

Roberta is still seeking a permanent family. (Nine)

Following emergency treatment, the dogs were transported to the Gold Coast, where Terri is now recovering in foster care.

"Stray dogs can find themselves in tricky situations but they are very good at adapting and overcoming," Animal Welfare League rehoming manager Mikaela Thrift said.

"Terri had pyometra and required emergency surgery which RAA provided for her before she got down here and that surgery saved her life."

While Terri and most of her pups have found homes, one pup named Roberta is still seeking a permanent family.

"She is looking for someone to take her under their wing and guide her, do puppy school but she is very, very sweet," Thrift said.

title: Empty piece of prime real estate costing taxpayers thousands
text:
A prime piece of Adelaide real estate that was meant to host a $600 million art gallery is instead sitting vacant and costing taxpayers more than $100,000 every year.

The land, formerly part of the Royal Adelaide Hospital site, has become a point of contention as the project faces delays and funding challenges.

The original proposal for a National Aboriginal Art Centre on the site was made in 2018 with $200 million in funding.

A prime piece of Adelaide real estate that was meant to host a $600 million art gallery is instead sitting vacant. (Nine)

However, following the change in government in 2022, the project was put on hold due to a reported $50 million cost blowout.

While a review of the project was completed in 2023, it has not been released to the public, but Premier Peter Malinauskas has acknowledged that construction costs could now reach $600 million.

9News can reveal taxpayers are being slugged upwards of six figures every year for weeding, security and upkeep of the empty Lot 14 site, with the plan to convert it into the Tarrkarri First Nations Cultural Centre still far from complete.

"We want to preserve the building site to ensure that … we haven't let the site degrade and spend more money," cabinet minister Tom Koutsantonis said.

READ MORE: Katter faces calls to apologise or resign after doubling down on threat ﻿

The state government is seeking additional funding from both the Commonwealth and private donors.

The premier's department contacted billionaire Andrew "Twiggy" Forrest's Minderoo Foundation in May, proposing a meeting between Forrest and Malinauskas.

9News understands that meeting has not yet eventuated, meaning no funding proposal by Minderoo is on the table.

Santos, BHP, Beach Energy and whoever buys the Whyalla Steelworks will be canvassed as potential donors.

But until secure funding is obtained, taxpayers will continue to bear the cost of maintaining the vacant site.

title: Derryn Hinch makes startling revelation about his final act
text:
The indestructible Derryn Hinch is sitting near his walking frame, recovering from a "bad fall", contemplating life in a nursing home and the possibility of being a candidate for voluntary assisted dying.

He admits he has only "a few years left" and there's time for reflection, but no regrets.

Examples: he doesn't like being called the "human headline", doesn't think he has often been wrong, admits to being inconsistent, agrees he was an alcoholic but still drinks, says one of his toughest times was being falsely accused of rape, and claims that he is in no way arrogant, something which may surprise some.

Hinch is 81 now, and after four wives, 17 sackings, three stints as a prisoner, several dances with death and treating his liver like a punching bag for decades he's still competitively driven, preparing in advance for criticisms he suspected would be raised in this discussion.

I spoke to him for my podcast Neil Mitchell Asks Why? at his city flat, which is small but has some of the most magnificent views in Melbourne.

It is here, surrounded by personal memorabilia, that he reads, sleeps, does puzzles and "cloud watches".

It's an age away from the opening nights, long lunches, Rolls-Royces and pay cheques which today would still be staggering.

Derryn Hinch has lived many lives: a broadcaster, a senator, several marriages and a litany of health issues. (Alex Ellinghausen)

Of course, even with age, some things never change.

The man whose every hiccough has been public property for more than 40 years is happy to share his battles with the pain of ageing.

"Originally, I thought I didn't ever want to go into a nursing home," Hinch told me.

"But I'm told now by some of the nursing homes I've been talking to that you can still socialise there and it's not like you are locked away."

And death?

He's had liver cancer, a liver transplant, facial melanoma that required significant radiation treatment, a life-threatening blood infection, and recently cardiac arrhythmia, where the heart doesn't beat properly and is effectively stopped and restarted to get back into rhythm.

"I'm very lucky that my brain still seems to be going," he said.

"Some people will dispute that, but it seems to be.

"But if my brain went, I've told my medical attorney not to revive me."

And would he consider voluntary assisted dying?

"Yes, I would. Yes. One of my best friends, Bob Rogers, did have his life taken by voluntary assisted dying because he had no quality of life.

"He couldn't go to the toilet by himself. He couldn't shower. He couldn't dress himself.

"And the last time I took him out to lunch I had to get on my hands and knees to lift his feet into a taxi.

"I thought, 'This is not living.'"

Rogers, who was 97, died in May last year.

He was a broadcasting icon for over 78 years.

Hinch, who was described as a spokesman for the Rogers family after the death, once offered to fly with Rogers to a Zurich euthanasia clinic and "be with him while he went".

But the family did not agree.

READ MORE: ﻿ Huge snowfalls push ski season into spring

Late radio icon Bob Rogers. (Nine Entertainment)

Hinch himself has been close to death at least twice.

His liver transplant was 14 years ago and was, he says, a "punt".

The donor liver came from a drug addict and may have carried dangerous infections.

It later emerged that without the surgery, Hinch would have been dead in two weeks.

But he remains a committed atheist, not having a "bob each way" as the inevitable approaches.

"When you're dead, you're dead. I don't believe in heaven and I get uncomfortable when people say, 'Oh, he will meet so and so upstairs.'

"I find that pretty embarrassing.

"I stopped taking communion when I was about 12 and told my parents I didn't believe it anymore. I have no belief at all."

Except, perhaps, self-belief.

His mind remains sharp and the strong self-belief hasn't faded.

He has no self-doubt.

Booze has been a constant in the Hinch life.

Lunches were marathons and he once wrote a newspaper column claiming to drink four bottles of white wine every day.

That's eight times the recommended daily intake, and exactly why he ended with cirrhosis of the liver.

He reluctantly agrees he "thinks" he was an alcoholic and says he stopped drinking for eight years out of respect for the donor of his liver.

He now drinks occasionally, he says.

So why the broken promise?

"It's partly because I've only got a few years left. I want to live well. But partly because my donor was a drug addict.

"I think I've made a deal with him."

READ MORE: ﻿ Friend of accused gunman says he could have network of supporters helping him

Derryn Hinch has been imprisoned three times. (Nine)

I've had many disagreements with Hinch over the years.

He showed few regrets as we argued the cases again, particularly how he reported the deaths of cricket legend David Hookes and television icon Graham Kennedy.

On the day of Hookes' funeral, Hinch broadcast that the cricketer had a girlfriend many didn't know about.

He claimed on-air Graham Kennedy "died with AIDS", which he now admits was "a mistake " and says he has apologised.

Admitting he was wrong does not come easily.

Hinch's catchphrase was always "all history owes the dead is the truth" while I argued publishing anything required a balance between benefit and hurt.

We still don't agree.

He was deeply upset by losing his Senate seat after only three years, but immensely proud of driving legislation to stop international travel by sex offenders.

As a commentator and a senator he has seen many politicians first hand: he gets on well with Anthony Albanese, thinks John Howard was a good leader, is very fond of Malcom Turnbull, thinks Bob Hawke was not a nice man, and Jeff Kennett is an enigma.

Hinch has been seriously broke, with less than $20 available at the ATM.

He has been very rich, and once owned two Rolls-Royces, one for himself and one for then wife Jacki Weaver.

They were different colours, he says.

There's no doubt he's been a trouble magnet, a larger than life tabloid journalist at times ahead of his time and at times infuriating with his uncompromising views.

In that sense, age hasn't changed him.

In Derryn's world, there are rarely shades of grey.

Lack of confidence has never been his problem, although he does say the nickname "human headline" seems "narcissistic".

This is how our discussion ended:

MITCHELL: You have no self-doubt. You stand by things you've done. You don't really see many mistakes in your life. Do you think you're arrogant?

HINCH: That's for you to decide.

MITCHELL: That's a political answer. You're back in the bloody Senate. What do you think?

HINCH: I don't think it's arrogant. I think it's just confidence.

MITCHELL: What's the difference?

HINCH: Donald Trump is arrogant. I'm self-confident.

title: Breaking: Australian economy beats low expectations with 1.8pc annual growth
text:
The Australian economy grew 0.6 per cent in the June quarter, slightly ahead of economist expectations.

Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) national accounts data show gross domestic product (GDP) grew 1.8 per cent over the past year.

"Economic growth rebounded in the June quarter following subdued growth in the March quarter, which was heavily impacted by weather events," said Tom Lay, the ABS head of national accounts.

Tropical Cyclone Alfred hit southern Queensland and northern New South Wales in early March, with strong winds and heavy rain causing huge disruptions to economic activity in those regions.

On the other hand, the June quarter would have received a boost from goods and services purchased to repair the damage in those regions.

The ABS said household and government spending were the key drivers of growth in the June quarter.

However, public investment was the largest detractor from growth, as many large public infrastructure projects have either been completed or delayed.

The ABS said trade also contributed to GDP growth, led by exports of mining commodities.

The ABS also noted that GDP per capita had increased 0.2 per cent in the June quarter quarter, following a decrease in the March quarter.

title: 'A persistent breakdown in trust': Scathing report into Canberra's libraries
text:
An independent working group looking into Libraries ACT has delivered a scathing report detailing issues within its workforce.

The report found that staff were regularly working overtime to ensure libraries stayed open and were being stretched in an effort to maintain services.

It found, among other issues, that issues around leave and "a culture of micromanagement" had led to staff burnout and poor morale.

Among the impacts on the public was the number of days libraries have had to shut their doors, which has more than doubled in the past 12 months.

The report found significant issues including with staffing, morale and burnout. (ABC News: Luke Stephenson)

In delivering the report, its authors made 37 recommendations, including an overhaul of rostering systems.

It also recommended changes for Civic and Erindale libraries, which have seen a drop in visitation numbers.

Staff morale a key issue

Staff morale was described in the report as an area in significant need of improvement, and one that was affected by inadequate staffing, frequent leave denials and unclear role expectations.

"Many staff report a reluctance to apply for leave due to fears of rejection, leading to a rise in unplanned absences that disrupt staffing and service continuity," the report found.

"Extended wait times for leave approvals, frequent leave denials, lack of transparency or consistency around leave considerations and a lack of role clarity and accountability have significantly impacted staff morale, contributing to reports of burnout."

Library staff gave feedback anonymously as part of the review. (ABC News: Luke Stephenson)

One staff member said inadequate staffing meant they could not attend public programs such as children's storytime without other areas of operations suffering.

"When I'm running a program, I can't help customers or shelve — it's all hands on the program," the staff member said.

Library closures primary concern

The working group was unable to pinpoint one particular factor behind the sharp increase in closures across Libraries ACT in the past 12 months.

In 2023-24, the number of days branches were closed was 42, while in 2024-25 there were 94 days.

"The recent increase in branch closures is a result of a series of complex and deeply embedded staffing, cultural, operational, and systemic issues," the report said.

"These have significantly affected staff morale, engagement and organisational cohesion and decreased community service delivery.

" At the core of these challenges lies a persistent breakdown in trust and communication at all levels ... this has created a work environment where many employees feel unsupported, disempowered and undervalued. "

Changes proposed for Civic and Erindale

The working group also examined Civic and Erindale libraries, finding their catchment areas overlapped with others and visitation numbers had dropped at both.

Civic Library, which is rented at more than $366,000 per year, is already proposed for a possible relocation as part of the Civic and Cultural District Master Plan.

The authors suggested exploring other models for these libraries, including something similar to the express library in use at Sydney City Council's town hall.

The report recommended developing a "transition plan" for both libraries within the next three to six months.

It also suggested adjusting opening hours at underperforming branches across the network.

The report recommended considering altering opening hours for some library branches. (ABC News: Luke Stephenson)

According to the report, Libraries ACT faces significant financial concerns, with a projected cash deficit of $1.7 million in 2025/26.

Meanwhile, 20 positions within its workforce remain unfunded, which the report said was the main driver of its deficit.

The report recommended temporarily restoring branch staff numbers to the level they were at in 2022/23, with funding allocated for two years.

It also recommended an overhaul of the rostering system, which it said had become "overly complex and inconsistent".

The working group said casuals were also an area that needed improving, finding that Libraries ACT was at risk of violating the Fair Work Act by keeping them on in an ongoing capacity.

It recommended providing casuals "with opportunities to apply for permanent or part-time roles as they become available, supporting workforce stability".

'Culture of micromanagement'

Closures of ACT Libraries branches increased significantly in the past 12 months. (ABC News: Matt Roberts)

The working group reported issues around how decisions were made within Libraries ACT, which they said contributed to the inefficiency plaguing the organisation.

"This structure has led to a culture of micromanagement, where leadership is hesitant to delegate authority and staff are reluctant to take initiative," it said.

"The result is a stalemate that fosters inefficiency, decision fatigue among senior leaders, and frustration among frontline staff who feel disempowered and undervalued," the report said.

It said many employees were "unsure of their responsibilities or how their roles align with broader organisational goals" and noted that more junior employees were often asked to train senior, higher-paid staff and new starters.

The report also detailed issues with transparency around decisions among leadership.

"Branch staff often feel that decisions are made without their input or consideration, and that communication from leadership lacks empathy and understanding," it said.

"In turn, enabling staff report that they face significant barriers in communication, often learning of critical incidents days or weeks after they occur."

Among the recommendations, the report authors suggested developing "a transparent, inclusive, and respectful communication culture to bridge the divide between staff and leadership".

Workplace culture 'toxic for a number of years': union

Community and Public Sector Union (CPSU) ACT regional secretary Maddy Northam said the report showed staff within Libraries ACT were finally being listened to.

"The workplace culture there has been toxic for a number of years and CPSU members have been screaming out for something to be done," Ms Northam said.

"Thankfully, now there's been this report, and we have some recommendations that can be implemented hopefully very quickly."

CPSU Regional Secretary Maddy Northam said providing adequate staffing and addressing staff morale were priorities at Libraries ACT. (ABC News: Luke Stephenson)

Ms Northam said staff had been leaving libraries "because they couldn't handle the stress anymore".

"Now is the time for the government to show things are changing," she said.

"And really importantly, for the communities that rely on these library services every day."

Changes already made: minister

ACT City Services Minister Tara Cheyne said workers's human rights were being violated. ( ABC News: Ian Cutmore )

"Anyone who's read the report can feel how harrowing the situation has been for staff," City Services Minister Tara Cheyne said.

Ms Cheyne said "distrust" had developed between staff and leadership, and steps were already being taken to change the situation.

"[The report] shows that actually there's been numerous reviews and reports over the years that either staff aren't aware of the outcomes of or the recommendations have been cherry-picked and not all implemented," she said.

"And so my commitment to staff, which I shared with them when I personally shared the report with them, was to say my commitment to you is this is a process that will be led by you.

" Too much has happened to you without you and without you understanding why. "

The minister said some "different perspectives" had been brought in from other parts of the government around leave and rostering to enact changes.

One such change, Ms Cheyne said, was that branch managers were now working together each morning to discuss how to handle any unplanned absences, "rather than it being elevated to more senior levels that aren't necessarily in that operational environment".

Ms Cheyne said the government was also looking at opening hours to see whether they could be changed, including at branches that are open at night when few people visit.

Ms Cheyne said the issues around leave were a human rights concern and a working group had already been established to improve the system.

"That's one of the most uncomfortable parts of the report for me because it's a breach of human rights, it's a breach of workers' rights," she said.

"That process had been really opaque to staff about how decisions were made.

"Obviously, the community has been incredibly let down when we've had to close libraries as a result of these unplanned absences."

'An absolute disgrace'

Various reviews have been carried out into Libraries ACT over the years, most of them since 2019, and the report found little had come of them.

"In nearly all instances, there was no evidence of the implementation of these recommendations or any structured delivery programs that assigned responsibilities or established timelines for deliverables," the report said.

Canberra Liberals leader Leanne Castley described the report as "damning" and an "absolute disgrace". (ABC News: Ian Cutmore)

ACT Opposition Leader Leanne Castley was scathing in the wake of the report's release.

"It's a damning report," she said.

" To know that there's been many reviews over 20 years and another one has talked about poor culture, to the point where the libraries aren't able to stay open, as expected, and the minister has done nothing, is an absolute disgrace. "

Ms Castley called on the ACT government to act swiftly to address the issues.

"What we see is, it's not just libraries, unfortunately — it's health, it's corrective services, across the board, you ask government employees whether they feel supported by ACT Labor, I'm pretty sure you will find the same," she said.

title: Thousands of Hyundai i30s recalled over potentially deadly manufacturing defect
text:
More than 18,000 Hyundai vehicles have been recalled in Australia over a potentially deadly manufacturing defect.

Here's what you need to know.

Which Hyundai models are being recalled?

The recall is for the Hyundai i30 PD model from 2020 to 2021.

"Due to a manufacturing defect, the fuel pump impeller may become deformed under certain environmental conditions, interrupting the fuel supply," the recall notice said.

"If this occurs, the engine could stall, resulting in a sudden loss of motive power.

"A sudden loss of motive power while driving may increase the risk of an accident causing injury or death to vehicle occupants and/or other road users."

How do I check for recalls?

The manufacturer said they would be contacting affected car owners in writing, asking them to schedule an appointment to have the fuel pump impeller inspected and replaced free of charge.

A list of vehicle identification numbers of the affected cars is available on the Department of Transport website.

Other models recalled previously

This recall is one of several issues Hyundai vehicles have faced in recent years.

In January, more than 4,700 vehicles, including the Kona N (OS) and i30 Sedan N (CN7) models manufactured between 2020 and 2023 were recalled due to separate issues that could also cause stalling.

In 2021, owners of Hyundai Tucsons up to six years old were told to park their vehicles in an open space away from garages due to fears a manufacturing error could lead to the car's engine catching fire, even when turned off.

title: Queensland government considering reviving trial of left turn at red light rule
text:
Drivers in Brisbane may soon be able to turn left at red lights, with the state government considering reviving the road rule.

A previous trial of the rule was axed by the former Labor government in 2021 when it decided the time-saving benefits didn't outweigh safety risks.

The rule allowed drivers who have come to a stop to turn left at a red traffic light, provided they give way to other traffic, and was only able to be used at signposted intersections.

Figures from the Brisbane City Council (BCC) showed around 15 million turns had been made from the start of the trial in 2013.

At one point there was as many as 50 intersections where the rule was permitted, before it was steadily rolled back, with just 17 remaining by its end.

Time-saving benefits questioned

In 2021, former transport minister Mark Bailey said a study found motorists were saving just nine seconds, and causing risks to pedestrians.

Now, Brisbane Lord Mayor Adrian Schrinner has written to the government to advocate for a review of the road rule, and Transport Minister Brent Mickelberg says he is happy to look at it.

“We are open to this review and are seeking advice from the department on how it could be rolled out and what needs to be considered," Mr Mickelberg said.

" As our population grows, we need to ensure there is a responsible balance between safety, efficiency, and practicality for all road users. "

Lord Mayor Adrian Schrinner has written to the state government to request a review of the rule. (ABC News: Lucas Hill)

Brisbane feeling the traffic pressure

Some motoring and road safety experts have raised concerns, with a spokesperson for the Royal Automobile Club of Queensland (RACQ), saying they were not convinced the road rule would ease traffic woes in the city.

Loading...

"While left turn on red was originally introduced to improve traffic flow, evaluations in Queensland showed it increased risks for vulnerable road users like pedestrians and cyclists, without being able to be applied in enough locations to meaningfully reduce congestion," they said.

"It also created confusion among drivers about where it was permitted, leading to inconsistent and unsafe behaviour.

"RACQ believes safer alternatives — such as dedicated turn lanes, green arrows and slip lanes — are better long-term solutions for improving efficiency without compromising safety."

Scramble crossings allow pedestrians to cross diagonally. (ABC News: Dan Smith)

Chief executive of the Pedestrian Council of Australia Harold Scruby told ABC Radio Brisbane a better way to improve safety outcomes was through scramble crossings.

"It's a diagonal crossing. You'll see them all around the world, all through Asia, Europe and even America," he said.

"Pedestrians can cross either directly across the road or diagonally, so they don't have to cross the road twice.

" That means you re-prioritise pedestrians in the city, not the motorists. "

BCC acting infrastructure chair Danita Parry labelled the former government's decision to axe the trial as "heavy-handed and out of touch".

"The left turn on red trial was enormously successful, helping people get around our city sooner and safer," she said.

Ms Parry said the city council would work with the state government on initiatives like the trial to "help keep Brisbane moving."

title: Perth man loses several million dollars after years of unexplained bank transactions
text:
In 2018, Perth man Michael Alford had two successful businesses in mining communications and GPS tracking, but he had started to notice some strange transactions appearing on his bank statements.

Unfortunately, in that the same year he was also diagnosed with blood cancer, and spent six months undergoing chemotherapy, stepping away from the day-to-day management of the businesses during that time.

The odd transactions continued in 2019. Money was going out of his accounts, appearing as if it could be payments to him and his wife, but never appearing in their personal accounts.

"I had insurances for things like [cancer], and I did get paid some sums of money for that, but all of that money seemed to get drained away from my accounts over the next 12 to 18 months in varying capacities," Mr Alford said.

" We spoke to the banks about it and we never quite got to the bottom of it. "

Credit cut-off

Then his bank, Bankwest (now owned by Commonwealth Bank), seemed to want to stop doing business with him. It was happy for him to hold an account for personal funds only, but indicated it wanted his credit accounts gone.

"They were starting to want us to get rid of every [loan] facility we had, close any loans for commercial reasons only," he said.

"I can say I never defaulted once in my life on any of my credit, and my wife as well.

" The bank just didn't seem to want to deal with us anymore. "

The unexplained withdrawals continued, and by 2021 the couple had had enough.

"We decided we'd pack up and move away, move to Darwin and set up a new life.

"We had money. We thought we had money. But then the bank made us pay out every single [loan] facility we ever had, personally."

Despite years of requests, Michael Alford says he hasn't got the detailed information from his bank. (ABC News: Sharon Gordon)

Mr Alford said the bank's treatment had left the couple effectively "debanked" as a result of the unexplained transactions.

Debanking occurs when a financial institution declines or limits financial services to a customer because it believes their accounts are being used for money laundering or to finance criminal activities, including terrorism.

He thinks the mystery transactions have been flagged by the bank as potential fraud or money laundering.

Formal requests to the bank for more detailed information and statements so he can track down what has been happening with his funds have been unsuccessful.

"We've made formal requests to the bank saying, 'Look, we've got over five, six hundred different transactions, which we can't adjust or account for,'" he said.

" We've been asking for this information since way back in 2021, and we still haven't got the answers. "

A mysterious $12 million deposit

In January this year the couple's online banking account suddenly showed a $12 million deposit in their names, but that the money was "held elsewhere".

"It's not our money," he said.

He has no idea how it got there "and this is after a long time of asking the bank to help us try and rectify all of this information," he said.

Mr Alford has reported his problems to the police, the Australian Taxation Office and the Australian Financial Complaints Authority (AFCA), so far without success.

"We have multiple cases in with AFCA at the moment, and they have not been able to provide us with any response with the money saying 'held elsewhere.'"

He has also contacted Austrac — the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre — Australia's anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing regulator.

"We've still yet to hear a thing. We've not had any response from any of that."

Nearly broken and bankrupt

Mr Alford is adamant he is not involved in money laundering, and just wants help to understand what has happened with his money and his accounts, and the missing funds returned.

"It's been a really challenging, traumatic experience to try and explain from the outset," he said.

"If you can't get the answers, we just can't get to the bottom of it.

"We've had to sell every asset that we have just to close out any [loan] facilities and the like, and then just live on what money we've had.

"We've had to shut businesses down … because they weren't viable to keep running.

"We're nearly broken. I'm on the verge of bankruptcy."

Mr Alford estimates he had lost several million dollars over the years and has now engaged a lawyer for assistance to clear his name and get his money back.

Commonwealth Bank, the current owner of Bankwest, has been contacted for comment.

John Hammond, the Alfords' solicitor, described the bank's treatment as "oppressive and unconscionable".

"If this conduct was carried out by any other business there would be a full-scale investigation and heads would roll," Mr Hammond said.

"The Alfords deserve to know to whom their money was transferred, why there is an amount of $12,000,000 disclosed in their bank statements, why there is a statement that says 'monies held elsewhere.'"

title: How to Train Your Dragon composer on the staying power of film music
text:
John Powell wants to shout the entire Melbourne Symphony Orchestra a drink.

In fact, the English-born film composer feels so sorry for the amount of work the orchestra is about to do, that he says he'll buy them two drinks.

"The bill for the bar would be huge because I really owe them," he tells me from London, ruefully. "Especially the brass section … I really feel for them."

John Powell spoke to me on the eve of the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra performing a live music screening of the Academy Award-nominated animation classic, How to Train Your Dragon, featuring Powell's electrifying score, which includes a full orchestra, a choral section, old Celtic instruments and enough hard work by the brass section to keep animated dragons in flight for one and a half hours.

Powell's How To Train Your Dragon score is beloved among fans of the original film series. (via Dreamworks)

Both the Sydney Symphony Orchestra and the MSO have announced that they will perform the second movie in the franchise, How to Train Your Dragon 2, in 2026.

Film music on stage

Live film performances have now become so popular for Australian orchestras that they sell out upon announcement.

At the three packed Melbourne events in July, it was especially moving to see every kind of audience member excitedly at a classical music performance: from footballer types with mullets, to families, to music students, to young couples dating. Next year, the MSO will have four performances of the film.

Telling the story of a misfit young Viking, Hiccup, and his accidental friendship with the creature that is supposed to be his enemy — a sweet and fearsome dragon called Toothless — HTTYD is the first part of an epic trilogy that's beloved by music and film fans. The music frequently appears on all-time best film music lists.

Powell will return to Oz at the end of the year to score John M Chu's Wicked: For Good. (Supplied: John Wilson)

In Australia, Powell's score ranked 37 in the ABC Classic 100 Music for the Screen poll in 2022, and you can happily lose days down internet rabbit holes, watching music scholars and amateurs pore over the power and beauty of the composition. It's a cult of adoration that catches even this veteran of more than 70 film compositions by surprise.

"This score is on the forefront of anything that a lot of students I've ever met have said, especially more recently," Powell says.

How to Train Your Dragon was a creative triumph. The remake is fine Photo shows A young man in a green vest puts his hand out to touch the nose of a big black animated dragon with green eyes How to Train Your Dragon is the latest movie to be picked up by the live-action remake trend.

"It certainly makes me feel old because people who don't seem that young come up to me and say, 'Oh, this meant so much to me in my childhood'. It wasn't that long ago!"

It actually was. HTTYD was released by Dreamworks in 2010, with Powell working on the score a year before.

He'd been shown an early cut of the movie, and once he heard the Scottish accents of the Viking characters, he connected to his own Scottish heritage and the Celtic sounds emerged.

"As a kid, my grandmother used to ask me to play for her, so I had to play reels and things on the fiddle so that she could sing 'mouth music' — kind of Gaelic working songs … I probably let that just come out in a way that I hadn't had a film to be able to do that in. So, it was a flood of various influences, but one that I'd never really tapped into."

A life in music

Powell has talked about being taken to a performance of the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto at the age of seven, and having his head turned for all time.

As a child, he played the violin and viola, then studied the former at the Trinity College of Music, central London. After finishing college, he composed music for commercials, which led to a job as an assistant to composer Patrick Doyle on several film productions.

He moved to Los Angeles in 1997 and scored his first major film, Face/Off, going on to compose for films such as the Bourne and Happy Feet series, Shrek and Wicked, the second part of which he is anxiously trying to tie off when we talk. "I've still got another 15 minutes to write," he says.

Loading Instagram content

Powell says the secret to film composition is to watch the film he's been asked to score as any ticketholder would.

"As an audience member, I'm experiencing the story," he says.

"Then things well up, or I feel kind of a kinetic energy in certain places, or I feel where it should slow down and where I need as an audience member to feel, to be allowed to feel things.

"And obviously the flying [in HTTYD] was really the main inspiration. Test Drive was more complete than a lot of the other sequences when I first saw the film, so I think that was a big part of what inspired mostly everything about what people like in the score."

Test Drive, the scene when Hiccup finally manages to fly with his disabled dragon, is hailed by music critics as one of the most exhilarating film compositions of all time, and a brilliant cinematic depiction of what it would feel like to fly.

Powell's first film score was for the 1997 action film Face/Off. (Supplied: Rebecca Morellato)

Soaring inspiration

As well as the Oscar nod, Powell's score has received several award nominations, including recognition from the International Film Music Critics Association for Film Music Composition of the Year, yet it still astounds Powell to realise how revered the sequence of breathtaking animation and soaring music is.

"Yeah, I can't quite believe that that's the case," he says.

Powell was a member of legendary film composer Hans Zimmer's music studio, Remote Control Productions, (Supplied: Melinda Lerner)

Powell says the art of composition is often more chance than design.

The enduring musical motif of Test Drive, with its skirling drums and simple tune, wasn't always destined for that scene.

"I'd like to say I sit down and write themes for very specific scenes, but often I don't have a terribly specific intent. I'll sit at the piano ... and just scratch out some tunes … and you start playing around with these themes … and then you realise this is a tune for someone who's an outsider, or somebody who's an outsider who finds their way."

Powell says music as diverse as Florence and the Machine or Massive Attack might be the influence or the inspiration for a score, and he sounds as open to new music now as he might have ever been as a younger composer.

"All the music cues are keys, so you're trying every lock. And some of them not only unlock that one scene, but they unlock a whole set of things about how to do the score," he says.

"You need tunes that latch themselves onto story points … then you start playing with the tunes, you move them around. I'd like to tell you it's very organised, but it's mainly chaos until it settles down and reveals itself."

The Sydney Symphony Orchestra will perform the world premiere of How to Train Your Dragon 2 in Concert at the Sydney Opera House on June 25-28, 2026.

The Melbourne Symphony Orchestra will perform HTTYD2 at Hamer Hall from August 27-30, 2026.

title: Olympic medallists and Gout Gout join biggest Australian team for world champs
text:
Australian Athletics has named its biggest-ever team for a global meet, with five Paris Olympic medallists and teenage sensation Gout Gout among an 88-strong squad for the world championships.

Indoor high jump world champion Nicola Olyslagers and Paris pole vault gold medallist Nina Kennedy, coming back from hamstring surgery, will lead a star field team, which also includes Olympic discus bronze medallist Matt Denny.

Australian Athletics high performance general manager Andrew Faichney said the size and quality of the team reflected a rise in popularity in the sport on the back of huge performances on the global stage.

Nina Kennedy won pole vault gold at the Paris Olympics. (Reuters: Kai Pfaffenbach)

"We've witnessed a real shift, not just in performance, but in national relevance," Faichney said.

"This team reflects that change. They're world class athletes with the results to match but, just as importantly, they're carrying the momentum of a sport that has so much belief behind it.

"From podiums to grassroots, we're seeing the influence of this generation of athletes. They're showing what's possible and I'm looking forward to seeing them carry the flag for Australia in just a few weeks' time."

Aussies go 1-2 in high jump at indoor world championships Photo shows Nicola Olyslagers and Eleanor Patterson pose with Australian flags at the world indoor athletics championships high jump final. Nicola Olyslagers defends her indoor high jump world championship, with fellow Australian Eleanor Patterson second in Nanjing, China.

Seventeen-year-old Queenslander Gout will run the 200 metres but not the 100m in Tokyo.

Despite Gout's widely publicised push to break the 10-second barrier in the 100m — his best legal time is 10.17 seconds — Gout did not line up in the 100m at the national championships in April, which served as the qualifying event for the worlds.

National champion Rohan Browning will run the men's 100m alongside Paris Olympian Joshua Azzopardi, who made the cut after Lachlan Kennedy withdrew due to a hamstring injury.

Gout has been named to run the 200m after breaking Peter Norman's national record that stood for 56 years in December, and bettering it at his first senior international meet in June.

The world championships kick off on September 13, running through Sunday, September 21.

title: Australian BASE jumper who died in French Alps was 'positivity in a person'
text:
The body of a Queensland man who died BASE jumping in the French Alps has been returned to Australia.

A private service will be held to celebrate Matthew Bustin's life, which loved ones say he lived to the fullest.

The experienced skydiver and BASE jumper from the Sunshine Coast has been remembered as highly energetic and motivated.

BASE is an acronym for "buildings, antennas, spans (bridges) and Earth (cliffs)", and involves jumping off high objects, using a parachute to descend to the ground.

It is a high-risk and unregulated sport.

The Australian Base association says Australians mostly jump overseas as it is effectively illegal here.

Matthew Bustin, who worked as an abseiler doing high-rise building maintenance, had developed a love for the sport over the past decade.

The 37-year-old's passion had taken him across the world, from South America to Europe.

Matthew Bustin loved the feeling of flying. (Supplied: Sam Llewelyn)

He was 'always present'

Michael Bustin said his younger brother had a sense of adventure and determination — even from a young age.

"As a child he [Matthew] was always wanting to push the envelope with what he did," he said.

"He found interest in surfing on the Sunshine Coast. Him and his mates would make longboards out of timber from Bunnings and ride down the big Alexandra Headland hills.

" We would spearfish at Mooloolaba and along Point Cartwright … he'd be always wanting to be on adventures. "

Matthew Bustin's passion for BASE jumping took him around the world. (Supplied: GoFundMe)

Michael Bustin said his brother was also the "best uncle" who was always willing to help, no matter what was going on in his life.

"He would drive 100 kilometres to put my daughter to bed, read her a story book and then he'd get in his car and drive back. It was insane how dedicated he was to family," he said.

"He was always present, he was not distracted when you were talking to him, he'd always be listening.

"He didn't drag anyone down with his life admin stuff. He was just positivity in a person. You felt better about yourself when he was with you and he didn't have to say anything at all.

"I think that is what I love most about him."

Spectacular travels with mates

Michael Bustin said his brother's kind and energetic nature allowed him to build a community of friends across the world.

"That's what made him so loved in the skydiving and BASE jumping community, you needed that energy around you in that sport," he said.

Their love of skydiving and BASE jumping took Matthew Bustin and his friends around the world. (Supplied: Sam Llewelyn)

Close friend Sam Llewelyn said their group of friends had been to some of the most remote and spectacular places on Earth.

"[You're] In the French Alps, probably one of the most beautiful parts of the world, fresh air, nobody around, blue summer days, and you're on top of the mountain, the most picturesque mountains in the world, and your standing next to three of your best mates zipping up your suits," he said.

Mr Llewelyn said Matthew Bustin, or "Busto" as they called him, had an infectious energy that drew people to him.

"He was a very unique man, very happy, very loving," his friend said.

" He'd connect with you, and you know he'd give you a hug that felt like your mother's. "

Global support for the family

The Sunshine Coast man's family launched an online fundraiser to help cover the costs of bringing him home.

Matthew Bustin and his friends together on one of their many adventures. (Supplied: Sam Llewelyn)

Within two days, they had raised more than $23,000, with donations from across the world.

"I've got messages from England, France Germany, Canada, Mexico, Brazil — people that I didn't know, but people who knew Matthew very well," Michael Bustin said.

He said the family would be holding a private celebration of his younger brother's life.

They also plan to donate the remaining money from the fundraiser to the French helicopter service that recovered Matthew Bustin.

title: Bunuba people say 'it's good to be home' as they return after floods
text:
Far along a bumpy dirt track, off the famous Gibb River Road in Western Australia's far north, Bunuba woman Monique Middleton sits on a pandanus-rich riverbank, surrounded by family.

It's the first time they have returned since catastrophic floods more than two years ago devastated the region.

"Our heart is here," she says.

"This is where my great-grandmother was born at Mornington."

With most of Ms Middleton's family living in Fitzroy Crossing, more than 380 kilometres away via corrugated roads, visits to their country Malunggu are difficult to coordinate.

Monique Middleton has coordinated a project with the Australian Wildlife Conservancy to assess flood damage. (ABC Kimberley: Dunja Karagic)

Malunggu is today part of a wildlife sanctuary called Mornington, more than 400,000 hectares of bush belonging to several native title groups, family holders and traditional owners including Bunuba and Kija people.

Since 2001 the Australian Wildlife Conservancy (AWC) has held the pastoral lease, working to protect more than 200 species of birds, marsupials and reptiles that inhabit the area.

Together with the AWC, Ms Middleton has dedicated "a lot of effort" and time in developing a collaborative post-flood recovery project, which was jointly funded by the federal and WA governments under the disaster recovery funding arrangements.

"The focus since the flood is coming back to Malunggu, looking at how the flood affected [the area] since the last time we were here," she says.

"But also reconnecting back through our cultural obligations that we have to follow, that we were taught."

Flood damage

In January 2023 "once-in-a-century" catastrophic floods ripped through the Fitzroy Valley, in the aftermath of ex-Tropical Cyclone Ellie.

AWC regional operations manager and conservation ecologist Skye Cameron says it had "devastating impacts" on Mornington.

"It was complete devastation to all our facilities," Dr Cameron says.

"The water was up to the roofs, we lost all our equipment, we lost a herbarium we've been collecting for 20 years, all that historical knowledge from AWC

The flood devastated infrastructure at Mornington. (Supplied: AWC)

"We're building resilience and how we operate in this landscape, and it's enabled us to re-look and re-establish some of those key connections with Bunuba."

As part of the grant, AWC and traditional owners visited sacred sites by car and helicopter to assess the damage and recovery after the floods.

Traditional owners and the AWC visited cultural sites via helicopter to assess any flood damage. (ABC Kimberley: Dunja Karagic)

"The aim of this camp is to get out and actually look at how badly they were impacted by the flood and what we can do in the future to build some resilience into those areas," Dr Cameron says.

Recovery of cultural sites

Travelling along a bumpy track away from the riverbank, elder Selina Middleton directs Dr Cameron through thick scrub towards a special cultural site she hasn't visited for years called a Nhaa Malay, which translates to honey increase site.

"We go to that area if we need more honey … all the things that live on honey we go and talk to the site and it gives us honey," she says.

" That site is very important to us. "

Stepping outside her vehicle towards a rock face, and peering behind the scrub, Ms Middleton begins calling out to the site in language.

"I just asked it if they can give us more honey," she says smiling.

Together on an app, they begin documenting any damage and weeds that have emerged in the region.

As part of the grant, traditional owners and the AWC are recording how sites have recovered after floods. (ABC Kimberley: Dunja Karagic)

"Every time we go to a site that's important to people, we can record and take photos, store that data and then they can use that information into the future," Dr Cameron says.

"If they come back to a site in a year or two, or 10 or 20 years, they can go, 'Oh, that's what it used to look like, this is how it's changed.'"

Younger generations reconnecting

It has been two decades since Bunuba man Barry Middleton has returned to where his grandmother was born.

"It's good to be back home," he says, looking out at the river.

Barry Middleton says it is "good to be back home" to the land where his grandmother was born. (ABC Kimberley: Dunja Karagic)

"It brings back lots of memories. My mothers and uncles used to tell me stories about this place … when I was a kid."

He says his uncle took him here when he was a child, but it wasn't until he was older that he learnt about how colonialism forced his grandmother to leave her country.

"It's good to see … how my grandmother used to survive and live off this land, on the hills, near the rivers … it's very hard to understand how hard life was living along these hills, these rivers and these springs," he says.

The children have been connecting with their country. (ABC Kimberley: Dunja Karagic)

"It was a difficult life, when they first saw white man, that became difficult, my grandmother didn't explain things to me, but my mother told me."

As young kids laugh on the riverbank and compete to throw rocks the furthest into the water, teenagers Zamarli, Justice and Jazlyn spend the day kayaking down the stream.

"It feels good, connecting back to families," Zamarli says.

Zamarli, Jazlyn and Justice say it feels good to be on country. (ABC Kimberley: Dunja Karagic)

For Mr Middleton, it's special seeing the young ones connecting to their country for the first time.

"We'll tell them what they told us, 'It's your place, make sure you look after the place,'" he said.

"They're doing things they don't do in town. You've got kids walking around in circles in town, but here you've got everything to see, climb hills, swim in the river, walk in the scrub.

" That's how we grew up as kids. "

title: Federal agencies face backlash over role in hidden gas leak 'scandal'
text:
Federal government agencies are facing a backlash over their dealings with gas giant Santos, which allowed a major methane leak to be kept secret from the public for years.

The ABC this week revealed a design flaw in a storage tank at the Darwin Liquefied Natural Gas (DLNG) plant led to it leaking thousands of tonnes of climate-polluting methane since its inception in 2006.

Despite this, Santos has been cleared to use the faulty tank until 2050 for its new Barossa gas project without fixing the leak or measuring emissions, in what environmentalists have branded a "national scandal".

This followed advice to Santos over the leak from the federal Clean Energy Regulator and CSIRO, which neither agency has been willing to detail publicly.

The location of the LNG tank in Port Darwin. ( )

The Clean Energy Regulator has told the ABC it has no record of any advice to Santos, despite the company reporting the leak to it by email in 2020.

The CSIRO, which Santos engaged as "independent and respected experts" for what to do about the leak, has refused to release records of its advice on the grounds this could harm its "commercial activities".

The ABC's revelations of the leak sparked criticism of the role of federal regulators from crossbench senators in Canberra, including David Pocock and Monique Ryan.

Federal Greens leader Larissa Waters said the party would call for an auditor-general review of "what is either a spectacular failure of regulators or a deliberate cover up by successive governments to protect a gas corporation's profit margin".

Senator Waters has also written to federal ministers questioning apparent inaction by the Clean Energy Regulator, as well as CSIRO's "financial relationship with Santos".

'No such documents exist'

An email obtained under Freedom of Information (FOI) shows that the day after Santos took control of the DLNG in May 2020, it asked the Clean Energy Regulator about how to report a spike in estimated emissions from the leak.

Santos told the regulator that its drone surveys on the DLNG tank "identified methane emissions of 832 tonnes per annum", which was more than what it had reported using guidelines under the National Greenhouse and Energy (NGER) scheme .

"We are seeking your confirmation that the drone monitoring results are not able to be used within NGER reporting?" it said.

However, when the ABC applied under FOI for any responses, the Clean Energy Regulator said "no such documents exist".

The Clean Energy Regulator said it had "undertaken extensive searches of all relevant electronic and hard copy databases and filing systems for the documents you have requested, however has been unable to locate any existing documents that contain the information you are seeking".

"Based on these searches, I am satisfied that all reasonable steps have been taken to locate any documents relevant to your request, but no such documents exist."

In response to questions from the ABC about the advice, the regulator said it "does not generally comment on advice provided to individual regulated entities about their specific circumstances".

The estimated leak was the equivalent of more carbon emissions a year than nearly one in four companies that reported to the Clean Energy Regulator in 2023-24.

CSIRO secrecy over 'commercial activities'

Documents obtained under FOI show Santos also paid the CSIRO for advice on what to do about the leak.

The company engaged CSIRO as "independent and respected experts to provide a recommendation on the best course of action to take from here with regards to remediation and prevention", an officer from the Northern Territory Environmental Protection Authority said in a November 2020 email.

This was a "really good outcome as it is very similar to the recommendation we discussed and proposed", the officer said.

However, the CSIRO refused to release details of its research to the ABC under FOI because to do so could harm its "commercial activities".

"The research commissioned was carried out by CSIRO on a commercial basis, on a full cost-recovery basis, in direct competition with the private sector," it said.

"CSIRO's undertaking of this commercial activity, and with it the experience, knowledge and trust gained, is also reasonably anticipated to generate similar commercial opportunities for CSIRO in the foreseeable future by virtue of increasing CSIRO's attractiveness to industry stakeholders in this field.

"The release of the research and analysis described in the relevant document would damage CSIRO's ability to secure those future commercial opportunities, while also damaging its existing relationships with industry, causing a clear detriment to CSIRO where it is working in direct competition with the private sector."

Call for disclosure

Larissa Waters has called for the disclosure of Santos payments to CSIRO for its advice on the gas leak. ( )

In a letter to the federal minister responsible for CSIRO, Tim Ayres, Senator Waters said there was "no evidence that [the agency has] taken any action to limit the leaking of methane or advise relevant departments or agencies with these regulatory responsibilities".

She called for the disclosure of CSIRO's advice and all financial agreements with Santos.

"In light of CSIRO's role as the appointed monitor of the methane leak, on this occasion it gives rise to a perception that the reason for their passivity and secrecy can be attributed to the financial relationship between the CSIRO and Santos," she said.

Senator Waters also wrote to Climate Change Minister Chris Bowen asking "what the [Clean Energy Regulator has] done to inform you on this persistent methane leak [and] how it has been allowed to continue".

She asked, "If these emissions have been included in our national greenhouse accounts, and what can be done by the federal government to require Santos to repair or replace the leaking tank before any shipments from Barossa arrive?"

The NT EPA has said the leak at DLNG poses no immediate threat to the community or the environment, and repairing it is a "commercial decision for Santos".

It says the methane emissions are a concern because they will contribute to global warming, but this was a matter for the Clean Energy Regulator.

Santos has said the tank is safe and fit for use until 2050, that DLNG has all relevant regulatory approvals, and it reports emissions in line with national guidelines.

title: 'Snapshot of Māori past': Carvings handed back to descendants
text:
They depict Māori ancestors, they have been described as cultural treasures, they are made from wood and shell — and they are now returning home after more than a century overseas.

Two ornate carvings, called "pou", that have been in the South Australian Museum's collection for more than 130 years are now destined for New Zealand after a ceremony in Adelaide on Tuesday.

The repatriation has been made possible by the work of many in the Māori community, and is part of efforts by museums around Australia to give back cultural objects to their countries of origin.

The wood carvings, with abalone shell inlay, depict four Māori ancestors. (ABC News: Sarah Maunder)

The SA Museum said the outcome followed a "historic decision" to return the carvings to the Tamatea Pōkai Whenua (TPW) cultural corporation, based at Hastings on the east coast of New Zealand's north island.

"These carvings are a snapshot of our past," said TPW chair Pōhatu Paku, who was in Adelaide for the ceremony.

" It's very important in the sense that they are carrying almost like a time-stamp. "

Tamatea Pōkai Whenua (TPW) cultural corporation chair Pōhatu Paku and son RJ attended the ceremony. (ABC News: Sarah Maunder)

The wood carvings, with abalone shell inlay, depict four Māori ancestors.

The SA Museum said the pou had been in its collection since 1891 and were part of a group of about 60 that was commissioned by Māori chief and parliamentarian Karaitiana Takamoana for a meeting house, or "wharenui", in the 1870s.

But the project was abandoned after he died and the items were instead sent to Dunedin, before being dispersed across the globe.

On Tuesday, the museum handed back the carvings to descendants of Karaitiana Takamoana at a ceremony, or "poroporoaki", featuring traditional song.

Brothers Reyne and Zenon Waetford were delighted to be in attendance.

A crowd gathered as the carvings were loaded onto a truck. (ABC News: Sarah Maunder)

"It's pretty heartwarming," Reyne said.

"I found it pretty emotional," Zenon added.

" I'm not fluent in Māori, but it's almost like you can feel the words that are being spoken, and you can almost tell what's going on, just by body language. "

Jonathon Waetford, from Māori cultural group Kotahitangā O Adelaide, was part of the ceremony and said it felt like a "farewell".

"It feels very liberating to witness a prominent museum release these treasures," he said.

"It also fills me with hope — this being one of the first [museums], that I know of, to be able to give these treasures back."

Jonathon Waetford, from Māori cultural group Kotahitangā O Adelaide, attended the ceremony. (ABC News: Sarah Maunder)

The SA Museum is understood to be the first institution outside of New Zealand to return its pou to the TPW.

"It brings a lot of healing back to us," Mr Paku said.

"All of the museums [in New Zealand] that have been housing these pou have agreed for their return, which is great.

"The South Australian Museum here in Adelaide is the first of the international repatriation, so it's very exciting — shortly we will be looking at North America and talking with some of the museums over there, so it's a staged approach."

The two-and-a-half-metre carvings will be loaded onto a plane in Melbourne. (ABC News: Sarah Maunder)

Mr Paku's son RJ said the pou had intergenerational significance.

"It's important for young ones to carry on the knowledge and let it be passed down," he said.

Repatriation of cultural remains and artefacts stored in museums has been gaining momentum across the world in recent years.

In 2019, the remains of 11 Kaurna ancestors in the Natural History Museum in London were returned to country in Adelaide's south, and Germany's Grassi Museum last year returned Kaurna artefacts which had spent more than 180 years overseas.

The pou will be transported to Te Whare o Heretaunga, near Hastings.

Heritage and repatriation manager Anna Russo says the museum wants to build "relationships with traditional custodians". (ABC News: Sarah Maunder)

The journey of the two-and-a-half-metre carvings back to New Zealand will take several days — they will be driven to Melbourne, then loaded onto a plane.

A freight company that specialises in the transport of cultural items will oversee the carvings' trip home.

The SA Museum's Aboriginal heritage and repatriation manager Anna Russo said the return was an act of mutual respect.

"It's particularly important for us because we need to build our relationships with traditional custodians, we need to be responsible allies, authentic allies," she said.

"For us here at the museum, we received the claim maybe about 12 months ago and just worked on it and started meeting with the claimants and talking about their ambitions.

"We need to work with traditional custodians to bring out the best stories in the collections, and when that means returning the collections … they should go home."

title: The world-famous musicians who still call Australia home
text:
With the exception of names like our grand Dames of opera, Nellie Melba and Joan Sutherland, Australia's track-record of nurturing talent here at home hasn't always been stellar.

Conductor Simone Young, arguably one of Australia's most successful exports since Sutherland, ventured overseas to build her career after facing challenges in the Australian landscape. For the last 30 years, Young honed her skills in Europe's major opera houses and orchestras.

In 2022, Young became Chief Conductor of the Sydney Symphony Orchestra, giving Australian audiences a consistent chance to see her in action.

Young isn't the only Australian hitting goals both here at home and around the globe.

More Aussies on the world stage

It's been a great year for Australian musicians on the world stage.

This month Daniel Carter starts his post as Music Director of the German National Theatre and State Orchestra in Weimar, Germany, a position previously held by J.S Bach, Franz Liszt and Richard Strauss. And Ingrid Martin was appointed Assistant Conductor of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra.

Simone Young live with the Sydney Symphony Orchestra Photo shows Australian conductor Simone Young holding her baton above her head. Live from the Sydney Opera House, hear Simone Young conduct the Sydney Symphony in music by Richard Strauss, also featuring pianist Andrea Lam. 8pm, Friday September 5.

There are hundreds more Aussies doing great things around the world. Enough to form an entire orchestra, the Australian World Orchestra. Their members are drawn from far-flung places including Berlin, Chicago, Los Angeles, Hong Kong, London and more.

Luckily for us, many of these musicians regularly perform in Australia. The Australian World orchestra is coming together this week for performances in Sydney and Melbourne.
